repositories.citation: tinacms. "TinaCMS - Open Source Headless CMS." GitHub, 2025. https://github.com/tinacms/tinacms
repositories.architecture: Git-backed headless CMS with visual editing toolkit for React frameworks. Content stored as files in repository, GraphQL layer for querying, React-based admin interface.
repositories.usage_example: Create Next.js blog with TinaCMS: npx create-next-app --example cms-tina. Edit content at /admin route with visual editing.

repositories.architecture: Collection of starter projects demonstrating TinaCMS integration patterns across frameworks
repositories.usage_example: Clone examples repo, cd into desired example, npm install && npm run dev

repositories.architecture: Minimal Next.js + TinaCMS boilerplate showcasing static generation patterns
repositories.usage_example: Best practices example for Next.js Static Generation with TinaCMS API

production_users.name: Unity Technologies
production_users.scale: Enterprise (Pokemon Go, Call of Duty engine)
benefits: GraphQL API for AI chatbot integration

production_users.name: Smashing Magazine
production_users.scale: Tens of thousands of posts and pages

documentation_sites.why_it_works: Markdown native + Git workflow natural for docs

marketing_websites.why_it_works: Visual editing empowers marketing teams without technical skills

publishing_editorial.why_it_works: Git branches enable natural editorial workflow

common_patterns: Next.js Pages Router + TinaCMS + Netlify/Vercel deployment
Branch-based editorial workflow with preview deployments
Protected main branch to prevent accidental publishes
DigitalOcean Spaces or Cloudinary for media management
Custom field types for structured content
best_practices: Use branch-based workflows for editorial approval
Define custom fields for content consistency
Optimize auto-generated GraphQL queries (don't rely on defaults)
Start simple with content model, add complexity as needed
pitfalls: Auto-generated GraphQL queries can be unoptimized
Work can be lost in editor (save frequently)
Branch protection requires special GitHub app permissions
Separate content repos require tina folder in both repos
Version mismatches between tinacms and @tinacms/cli cause build errors
GitHub Pages deployment needs manual configuration
emerging_trends: Git-based CMS gaining traction among developers
AI integration with content (Unity's chatbot example)

implementation_recommendations.rationale: Markdown-native perfect for docs, Git workflow natural for engineers, visual editing empowers technical writers, GraphQL API enables search/AI integrations
Visual editing eliminates dev dependency for content updates, fast performance for SEO, branch previews for review, affordable pricing
Git branches map to editorial workflow naturally, preview before publish, content ownership in repo, massive performance vs WordPress
Fast repeatable setup, client-friendly editing UI, modern tech stack, portable content (markdown)

implementation_recommendations.scenario: Large enterprise with complex collaboration needs
implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: DO NOT USE TinaCMS - Use Sanity instead
implementation_recommendations.rationale: TinaCMS lacks real-time collaboration, has small community, limited self-hosting. Sanity offers better enterprise features, compliance (SOC 2, GDPR), real-time collab.

implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: DO NOT USE TinaCMS - Use Sanity or Contentful
implementation_recommendations.rationale: TinaCMS is React-only (Next.js, Gatsby). Other frameworks not supported and no timeline for support.

implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: DO NOT USE TinaCMS - Use Shopify + Sanity or Contentful
implementation_recommendations.rationale: Limited content modeling for products, no native e-commerce features, better specialized options exist

implementation_recommendations.recommended_solution: DO NOT USE TinaCMS - Use Contentful
implementation_recommendations.rationale: TinaCMS interface not designed for mobile screens, image dialogs don't fit, save buttons inaccessible

controversial_topics: Self-hosting capabilities (community wants more, team cautious)
Framework support (demand for Vue/Svelte vs React-focused philosophy)
Markdown limitations (some want richer editing, others love simplicity)
App Router support timing (slow modernization criticism)
expert_opinions: "Tina as proof-of-concept and interesting direction in headless CMS ecosystem" - Developer reviewer
"TinaCMS has been a game-changer for SSW" - SSW testimonial
"6x page speed improvement while maintaining editorial workflow" - Smashing Magazine
"Great live-editing experience, valuable for non-tech-savvy editors" - User review
"Lost work twice, wouldn't rush to use it again" - Critical reviewer
"Interface clearly not meant for mobile screen sizes" - Mobile user feedback

visual_editing.feedback: Best-in-class live editing, click-to-edit with instant feedback, preview before commit

git_workflow.feedback: Content ownership in repo, version control native, branch-based editorial workflow natural for developers

markdown_support.feedback: Perfect for documentation, portable content, developer-friendly format

developer_experience.feedback: Next.js integration seamless, GraphQL API flexible, customizable fields and schemas

performance.feedback: 6x improvement reported (Smashing Magazine), static generation benefits, edge deployment compatible

collaboration.feedback: Developer-marketer collaboration improved, no roadblocks for non-technical users

pricing.feedback: Affordable for small teams ($29/mo), competitive vs alternatives

framework_support.issue: React-only (Next.js, Gatsby). No Vue, Svelte, Angular. No App Router or React Server Components.
framework_support.impact: Limits adoption, framework lock-in, can't use modern Next.js features

mobile_experience.issue: Interface not designed for mobile, image dialogs don't fit, buttons inaccessible

editor_stability.issue: Reports of lost work in editor, WYSIWYG markdown editor 'underdone', no HTML support in markdown
editor_stability.impact: Trust issues, content loss risk, limited formatting
editor_stability.workaround: Save frequently, use external markdown editor

community_size.issue: Small community vs competitors (19k downloads/week vs Sanity's 168k), low Stack Overflow presence
community_size.impact: Less troubleshooting help, fewer community solutions
community_size.workaround: Rely on official docs and GitHub issues

repository_complexity.issue: Separate content repos require tina folder in both, AstroJS incompatibility, not documented well
repository_complexity.impact: Setup more complex than expected, some architectures not supported
repository_complexity.workaround: Keep content in same repo or avoid AstroJS

github_dependency.issue: Strong GitHub dependency, GitLab/Bitbucket not well supported, branch protection issues
github_dependency.impact: Vendor lock-in, access permission concerns, deployment friction
github_dependency.workaround: Accept GitHub dependency or self-host (limited features)

self_hosting.issue: Self-hosted backend lacks search functionality, limited features vs cloud
self_hosting.impact: Self-hosting not full-featured, compliance teams disappointed

real_time_collaboration.impact: Large teams face friction, simultaneous editing problematic

media_management.issue: Single media store limitation, complex to support multiple stores
media_management.impact: Projects with media in multiple locations struggle

choose_tinacms_when: Project uses Next.js Pages Router or Gatsby
avoid_tinacms_when: Using Vue, Svelte, Angular, or other non-React frameworks
Need React Server Components or Next.js App Router
Large team (>10 editors) needs real-time collaboration

tinacms_to_sanity.reason: Framework limitations, need real-time collab, enterprise features

rationale: Marketing team will benefit from visual editing immediately
Next.js Pages Router currently in use (good fit)
Content is markdown (portable if need to migrate later)
pros_for_choiz: Marketing team can edit without dev dependency
cons_for_choiz: Pages Router only (if migrating to App Router later)

use_tinacms_if: Tech stack: Next.js Pages Router (no migration plans)
consider_alternatives_if: Planning Next.js App Router migration soon → Wait or use Sanity
Budget allows $500+/mo → Consider Sanity or Contentful

implementation_plan.phase_1: Start with TinaCMS for current Pages Router setup
implementation_plan.phase_2: Monitor Next.js App Router support progress
implementation_plan.phase_3: Evaluate quarterly if TinaCMS meets evolving needs
implementation_plan.phase_4: Have migration plan ready (to Sanity) if limitations emerge

risk_mitigation: Content stored as markdown = portable if need to migrate
Start with $29/mo plan = low financial risk
Evaluate after 3 months before committing long-term
Keep alternative CMS (Sanity) as backup plan
